    [System Programming] 9-1Ïû•. ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Ï†úÏñ¥

    17 Î∂Ñ ÏÜåÏöî


    set-user-id Ïã§ÌñâÌååÏùº (Review)

    • ÌäπÎ≥ÑÌïú Ïã§ÌñâÍ∂åÌïú set-user-id(set user ID upon execution)
      • set-user-id ÏÑ§Ï†ïÎêú Ïã§ÌñâÌååÏùºÏùÑ Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÎ©¥
      • Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïú†Ìö® ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê IDÎäî Í∑∏ Ïã§ÌñâÌååÏùºÏùò ÏÜåÏú†ÏûêÎ°ú Î∞îÎÄú.
        • ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïã§Ï†ú ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê ID (real user ID)Îäî Í∑∏ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º Ïã§ÌñâÌïú ÏõêÎûò ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê IDÎ°ú ÏÑ§Ï†ïÎêúÎã§.
        • ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ changÏù¥ÎùºÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê IDÎ°ú Î°úÍ∑∏Ïù∏ÌïòÏó¨ Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû®ÏùÑ Ïã§Ìñâ ÏãúÌÇ§Î©¥ Í∑∏ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïã§Ï†ú ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê IDÎäî changÏù¥ ÎêúÎã§.
          • effective IDÎäî changÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Í∑∏ ÌååÏùºÏùò ÏÜåÏú†Ïûê
      • Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Îäî Ïã§ÌñâÎêòÎäî ÎèôÏïà Í∑∏ ÌååÏùºÏùò ÏÜåÏú†Ïûê Í∂åÌïúÏùÑ Í∞ñÍ≤å Îê®.
    • Ïòà : /usr/bin/passwd Î™ÖÎ†πÏñ¥ Ïã§Ìñâ ÌååÏùº
      • set-user-id Ïã§ÌñâÍ∂åÌïúÏù¥ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÎêú Ïã§ÌñâÌååÏùºÏù¥Î©∞ ÏÜåÏú†ÏûêÎäî root
      • ÏùºÎ∞ò ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÍ∞Ä ÏâòÏóêÏÑú Ïù¥ ÌååÏùºÏùÑ Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÍ≤å ÎêòÎ©¥, Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïú†Ìö® ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê IDÎäî rootÍ∞Ä Îê®.
      • /etc/passwdÏ≤òÎüº rootÎßå ÏàòÏ†ïÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÌååÏùºÏùò Ï†ëÍ∑º Î∞è ÏàòÏ†ï Í∞ÄÎä•


    Set-user-ID and set-group-ID (Review)

    • passwd programÎ•º Ïù¥Ïö©ÌïòÏó¨ passwordÎ•º Î∞îÍøÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞
      • passwd programÏùÑ Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÎäî ÎèÑÏ§ë Ïû†Ï†ïÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú rootÏùò Í∂åÌïúÏùÑ Î∂ÄÏó¨Î∞õÏùå.
        • Real user ID of passwd program: user ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏÉùÏÑ± Ïãú Î∂ÄÎ™®Ïùò ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê IDÏôÄ Í∑∏Î£π IDÎ•º Í∑∏ÎåÄÎ°ú Î¨ºÎ†§ Î∞õÏùå
        • Effective user ID of passwd program: root


    9.1 ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏÉùÏÑ±

    ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏÉùÏÑ±

    • fork() ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Ìò∏Ï∂ú
      • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÎòëÍ∞ôÏù¥ Î≥µÏ†úÌïòÏó¨ ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±
      • ÏûêÍ∏∞Î≥µÏ†ú(Ëá™Â∑±Ë§áË£Ω)
    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <unistd.h>
pid_t fork(void);
    • ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïúÎã§.
    • It is called once but returns twice.
    • ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏóêÍ≤åÎäî 0ÏùÑ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÌïòÍ≥† Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏóêÍ≤åÎäî ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°ú ÏÑ∏Ïä§ IDÎ•º Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÌïúÎã§


    • The child is a copy of parent.

      • Child gets a copy of the parent‚Äòs data, heap, and stack.

      • Parent and child often share the text segment.
        • Ïã§Ìñâ Ï§ëÏóê ÏΩîÎìúÎäî ÏàòÏ†ïÎêòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê
      • data, heap, stackÏùÄ Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§.
        • global Î≥ÄÏàòÎäî data ÏòÅÏó≠Ïù¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Ïù¥Î•º Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Í≤É

    • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò pidÏóêÎäî ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò pidÏù∏ 15066Ïù¥ Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÍ≥† ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò pidÏóêÎäî 0Ïùò Í∞íÏù¥ Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÍ≤å ÎêúÎã§.

    • PCÍ∞íÎèÑ Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Í∞ñÎçò Í∞íÍ≥º ÎèôÏùºÌïú Í∞íÏùÑ Í∞ñÍ≤å ÎêúÎã§.


    ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Ï£ºÏÜåÍ≥µÍ∞Ñ

    Î≥ÄÏàòÎäî ÏÑ†Ïñ∏Í≥º ÎèôÏãúÏóê Ï¥àÍ∏∞ÌôîÎ•º Î≥¥ÌÜµ ÌïòÎäîÎç∞ Í∑∏Î†áÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÄ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§. -> bss: generally 0ÏúºÎ°ú Ï¥àÍ∏∞Ìôî

    heap Íµ¨Ïó≠ÏùÄ ÎèôÏ†Å Î≥ÄÏàòÍ∞Ä Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎäî Í≥≥

    Ï†ïÏ†Å Î≥ÄÏàòÎäî Ïª¥ÌååÏùº Îê† Îïå ÏÉùÏÑ±ÎêúÎã§.


    ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏÉùÏÑ±

    • fork()Îäî Ìïú Î≤à Ìò∏Ï∂úÎêòÏßÄÎßå Îëê Î≤à Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÌïúÎã§.
      • ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏóêÍ≤åÎäî 0ÏùÑ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÌïòÍ≥†
      • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏóêÍ≤åÎäî ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ IDÎ•º Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÌïúÎã§.
      • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏôÄ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Îäî Î≥ëÌñâÏ†Å(concurrently)ÏúºÎ°ú Í∞ÅÍ∞Å fork() Ïù¥ÌõÑ Î¨∏Ïû•Ïùò Ïã§ÌñâÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜçÌïúÎã§.
      • Ï¶â, thread controlÏù¥ Îëê Í∞ú Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏù¥ ÎêúÎã§.


    fork1.c

    #include <stdio.h>
#include <unistd.h>
/* ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïúÎã§. */
int main()
{
     int pid;
     printf("[%d] ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë \n", getpid());
     pid = fork();
     printf("[%d] ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ : Î¶¨ÌÑ¥Í∞í %d\n", getpid(), pid); //Îëê Î≤à Ïã§Ìñâ
}

    $ fork1
[15065] ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë
[15065] ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ : Î∞òÌôòÍ∞í 15066
[15066] ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ : Î∞òÌôòÍ∞í 0


    Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏôÄ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Íµ¨Î∂Ñ

    • fork() Ìò∏Ï∂ú ÌõÑÏóê Î¶¨ÌÑ¥Í∞íÏù¥ Îã§Î•¥ÎØÄÎ°ú Ïù¥ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥Í∞íÏùÑ Ïù¥Ïö©ÌïòÏó¨
    • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏôÄ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º Íµ¨Î≥ÑÌïòÍ≥†
    • ÏÑúÎ°ú Îã§Î•∏ ÏùºÏùÑ ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§.
    pid = fork();
if ( pid == 0 )
{ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïã§Ìñâ ÏΩîÎìú }
else
{ Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïã§Ìñâ ÏΩîÎìú }


    fork2.c

    #include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
/* Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≥† ÏÑúÎ°ú Îã§Î•∏ Î©îÏãúÏßÄÎ•º ÌîÑÎ¶∞Ìä∏ */
int main() 
{
     int pid; 
     pid = fork();
     if (pid ==0) { // ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§
         printf("[Child] : Hello, world pid=%d\n", getpid());
     }
     else { // Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§
         printf("[Parent] : Hello, world pid=%d\n", getpid());
     }
}

    $ fork2
[Parent] : Hello, world pid=15799
[Child] : Hello, world pid=15800

    parentÏôÄ chileÏùò Ïã§Ìñâ ÏàúÏÑúÎäî Ï§ëÏöîÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏùå


    fork3.c: Îëê Í∞úÏùò ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏÉùÏÑ±

    #include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
/* Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Îëê Í∞úÏùò ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïúÎã§. */
int main()
{ 
    int pid1, pid2;
    pid1 = fork();
    if (pid1 == 0) {
        printf("[Child 1] : Hello, world ! pid=%d\n", getpid());
        exit(0); //child process Ï¢ÖÎ£å
    }
    pid2 = fork();
    if (pid2 == 0) {
        printf("[Child 2] : Hello, world ! pid=%d\n", getpid());
        exit(0);
    }
}

    $ fork3
[Child1] : Hello, world! pid=15741
[Child2] : Hello, world! pid=15742


    fork()

    13ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ

    • Example
    #include "apue.h"

int glob = 6; /* external variable in initialized data */
char buf[] = "a write to stdout\n";

int main(void)
{
    int var; /* automatic variable on the stack */ //uninitialized data
    pid_t pid;
    
    var = 88;
    if (write(STDOUT_FILENO, buf, sizeof(buf)-1) != sizeof(buf)-1)
        err_sys("write error");
    printf("before fork\n"); /* we don't flush stdout */
    
    if ((pid = fork()) < 0) {
        err_sys("fork error");
    } else if (pid == 0) { /* child */
        glob++; /* modify variables */
        var++;
    } else {
        sleep(2); /* parent */
    }
    
    printf("pid = %d, glob = %d, var = %d\n", getpid(), glob, var);
    exit(0);
}
    • Ïã§Ìñâ
    $ ./a.out
a write to stdout
before fork
pid = 430, glob = 7, var = 89
pid = 429, glob = 6, var = 88
$ ./a.out > temp.out
$ cat temp.out
a write to stdout
before fork
pid = 432, glob = 7, var = 89
before fork
pid = 431, glob = 6, var = 88
$

    We never know if the child starts executing before the parent or vice versa. - It depends on the process scheduling algorithm.


    fork()

    • Information shared by child and parent.
      • real-uid(gid), effective-uid(gid)
      • controlling terminal
      • current working directory, root directory
      • signal handlers : Ïù¥Î≤§Ìä∏ Î∞úÏÉù ÌÜµÏßÄ ÏàòÎã®
      • environment
      • resource limits
    • differences between child and parent.
      • the return value from fork.
      • PID and PPID
      • child‚Äòs resource utilizations are set to 0.
      • pending signals - signal handlerÎäî Í≥µÏú†ÎêòÏßÄÎßå signal Í∑∏ ÏûêÏ≤¥Îäî Í≥µÏú† x
    • Two main reasons for fork to fail
      • if there are already too many processes in the system.
      • if the total number of processes for this real user ID exceeds the system‚Äòs limit.
    • Two uses for fork (Ïôú forkÎ•º ÌïòÎäîÍ∞Ä?)
      • A process wants to duplicate itself.
        • Parent and child can each execute different sections of code at the same time.
        • Common for network servers.
      • A process wants to execute a different program.
        • Common for shells.
        • Child does exec() right after it returns from fork().


    ÏâòÏùò Íµ¨Ï°∞ (revisit)

    While (true) {
    display prompt
    read command (command, params) // Get command or execution file
    if (fork() != 0) then { // Execute command or execution file
		wait(&status); // fork a child, wait for a child to finish
		exit()
	}
	else
		execve(command, parmas) // ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§
	} // ÏûÖÎ†•Îêú Î™ÖÎ†πÏñ¥Î•º Ïã§Ìñâ

    $ ls
. .. /etc
/home /usr /dev
$ a.out
‚Ä¶.
$

    while(true){
	display prompt
	read command(command, params)
	if (fork()!=0) then {
		wait(&status);
		exit()
	}
	else
		exec(command, params)
}


    SIGCHLD

    • When a process terminates, the kernel sends the signal SIGCHLD to the parent.
      • By default, this signal is ignored, and no action is taken by the parent.
    • Processes can elect to handle this signal, however, via the signal( ) or sigaction( ) system calls
    • The SIGCHLD signal may be generated and dispatched at any time, as a child‚Äòs termination is asynchronous with respect to its parent.
      • Îî∞ÎùºÏÑú Î∞úÏÉù ÏãúÏ†ê ÏòàÏ∏° Î∂àÍ∞Ä.
    • But often, the parent wants to learn more about its child‚Äòs termination, or even explicitly wait for the event‚Äòs occurrence.
    • This is possible with the wait system calls


    wait() and waitpid()

    • A process that calls wait() or waitpid()
      • Block, if all of its children are still running.
      • Return immediately if a child has terminated.
      • Return immediately with an error, if it doesn‚Äôt have any child processes.(Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä child ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÏùÑ Îïå)
        • forkÎ•º ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† wait -> Ï¶âÏãú return


    ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Í∏∞Îã§Î¶¨Í∏∞: wait()

    • ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Ï§ëÏùò ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä ÎÅùÎÇ† ÎïåÍπåÏßÄ Í∏∞Îã§Î¶∞Îã§.
      • ÎÅùÎÇú ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ï¢ÖÎ£å ÏΩîÎìúÍ∞Ä statusÏóê Ï†ÄÏû•ÎêòÎ©∞
      • ÎÅùÎÇú ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Î≤àÌò∏Î•º Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÌïúÎã§. Ïò§Î•òÏãú -1 Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
pid_t wait(int *status);
pid_t waitpid(pid_t pid, int *statloc, int options);

    ÌååÎûÄÏÉâ ÏÑ†ÏùÄ blockÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî Îúª


    wait()

    #include <sys/wait.h>

pid_t wait(int *statloc);
 		Both return: process ID if OK, 0 (see later), or -1 on error
    • wait()
      • If a child has already terminated and is a zombie, wait returns immediately with that child‚Äôs status.
      • Otherwise, it blocks the caller until a child terminates.
      • If the caller blocks and has multiple children, wait returns when one terminates.
    • statloc argument
      • Pointer to integer
      • Store termination status (in case of normal termination) in the location pointed to by staloc.
        • And signal number (abnormal termination)
          • Ïôú ÎπÑÏ†ïÏÉÅ Ï¢ÖÎ£åÍ∞Ä ÎêòÏóàÎäîÏßÄÎ•º ÎÇòÌÉÄÎÇ¥Îäî Ï†ïÎ≥¥
        • And if core file was created


    forkwait.c

    #include <unistd.h> ‚Ä¶
/* Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≥† ÎÅùÎÇòÍ∏∞Î•º Í∏∞Îã§Î¶∞Îã§. */
int main()
{
    int pid, child, status;
    printf("[%d] Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë \n", getpid( )); 
    pid = fork(); 
    if (pid == 0) { 
        printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë \n", getpid( )); 
        exit(1);
    }
    child = wait(&status); // ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÎÅùÎÇòÍ∏∞Î•º Í∏∞Îã§Î¶∞Îã§.
    printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ %d Ï¢ÖÎ£å \n", getpid(), child);
    printf("\tÏ¢ÖÎ£å ÏΩîÎìú %d\n", status>>8); //Ï¢ÖÎ£åÏΩîÎìúÍ∞íÏùÄ 4Î∞îÏù¥Ìä∏ Ï§ë 3Î≤àÏß∏ Î∞îÏù¥Ìä∏ÏûÑ -> 8 shift
}

    $ forkwait
[15943] Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë
[15944] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë
[15943] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ 15944 Ï¢ÖÎ£å
Ï¢ÖÎ£åÏΩîÎìú 1


    macros for interpreting the termination status

    termination statusÎ•º Ìï¥ÏÑùÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú Îß§ÌÅ¨Î°ú Ìï®Ïàò - WIF

    • If not NULL, the status pointer contains additional information about the child (how the process terminated)
    • #include <sys/wait.h>
    • WIFEXITED (status);
      • returns true if the child process terminated normally
      • Ï†ïÏÉÅÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ï¢ÖÎ£åÌïú Í≤ΩÏö∞Ïóê Ï∞∏(TRUE) Í∞íÏùÑ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
      • WEXITSATUS(status)
        • WIFEXITED()Í∞Ä TrueÏù¥Î©¥ exit Ìï®ÏàòÏùò Ïù∏ÏûêÏóêÏÑú ÌïòÏúÑ 8 ÎπÑÌä∏ Í∞íÏùÑ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
    • WIFSIGNALED (status);
      • returns true if a signal that it did not catch caused the child process‚Äò termination (abnormal)
      • WTERMSIG(status) : if WIFSIGNALED is True, fetch the signal number that caused the termination.
    • WIFSTOPPED (status);
      • Child ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Ïã§ÌñâÏù¥ ÏùºÏãú Ï§ëÎã®Îêú Í≤ΩÏö∞Ïóê Ï∞∏ Í∞íÏùÑ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
      • WSTOPSIG(status)
        • if WIFSTOPPED is True, Child ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ïã§ÌñâÏùÑ ÏùºÏãú Ï§ëÎã®ÏãúÌÇ® ÏãúÍ∑∏ÎÑê Î≤àÌò∏Î•º Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
    • WIFCONTINUED (status);
      • return true if the process was continued, and is currently being traced via the ptrace( ) system call\
      • Ï§ëÏöî x


    • A process that calls wait or waitpid can
      • block (if all of its children are still running), or
        • wait() is called at any random point in time
      • return immediately with the termination status of a child, (SIGCHLD-asynchronous notification) or
        • ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ zombie process Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞
      • return immediately with an error (if it doesn‚Äòt have any child processes) errno value:
      • ECHILD - The calling process does not have any children.


    wait(): macros for interpreting the termination status

    • Example
    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
void pr_exit(int status)
{
    if (WIFEXITED(status)) //case 1
        printf("normal termination, exit status = %d\n", WEXITSTATUS(status));
    else if (WIFSIGNALED(status)) // case 2
        printf("abnormal termination, signal number = %d\n", WTERMSIG(status));
    else if (WIFSTOPPED(status)) // case 3
        printf("child stopped, signal number = %d\n", WSTOPSIG(status));
}



    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
int main(void)
{
    pid_t pid;
    int status;
    
    if ((pid = fork()) < 0)
        printf("fork error");
    else if (pid == 0) /* child */
        exit(7);
    
    if (wait(&status) != pid) /* wait for child */
        printf("wait error");
    pr_exit(status); /* and print its status */ // case 1 Ïã§Ìñâ
    
    if ( (pid = fork()) < 0)
        printf("fork error");
    else if (pid == 0) /* child */
        abort(); /* generates SIGABRT */ // ÎπÑÏ†ïÏÉÅ Ï¢ÖÎ£å
    
    if (wait(&status) != pid) /* wait for child */
        printf("wait error");
    pr_exit(status); /* and print its status */ //case 2 Ïã§Ìñâ
    
    if ( (pid = fork()) < 0)
        printf("fork error");
    else if (pid == 0) /* child */
        status /= 0; /* divide by 0 generates SIGFPE */
    
    if (wait(&status) != pid) /* wait for child */
        printf("wait error");
    pr_exit(status); /* and print its status */ // case2 Ïã§Ìñâ
}
    • Ïã§Ìñâ
    $ ./a.out
normal termination, exit status = 7
abnormal termination, signal number = 6
abnormal termination, signal number = 8
$

    Each signal number is defined in <signal.h>
SIGABRT: 6
SIGFPE: 8


    wait.c

    #include <unistd.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
int main (void){
    int status;
    pid_t pid;
    
    if (!fork ( )) //child
        return 1;
    pid = wait (&status); //parent
    
    if (pid == -1) //error
        perror ("wait");
    printf ("pid=%d\n", pid);
    
    if (WIFEXITED (status))
        printf ("Normal termination with exit status=%d\n", WEXITSTATUS (status));
    
    if (WIFSIGNALED (status))
        printf ("Killed by signal=%d%s\n", WTERMSIG (status), WCOREDUMP (status) ? "(dumped core)" : "");
    
	if (WIFSTOPPED (status))
		printf ("Stopped by signal=%d\n", WSTOPSIG (status));
    
	if (WIFCONTINUED (status))
		printf ("Continued\n");
    
	return 0;
}

    $ ./wait
pid=8529
Normal termination with exit status=1


    • If, instead of having the child return, we have it call abort( ), which sends itself the SIGABRT signal, we will instead see something resembling the following:
    $ ./wait
pid=8678
Killed by signal=6


    Waiting for a Specific Process

    #include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/wait.h>
pid_t waitpid (pid_t pid, int *status, int options);
	return: process ID if OK, 0 (see later), or -1 on error
    • Why waitpid() is required?
      • a process has multiple children, and does not wish to wait for all of them, but rather for a specific child process
      • wait() returns on termination of any of the children.
    • One solution would be to make multiple invocations of wait( ), each time noting the return value
      • wait() Ïó¨Îü¨Î≤à Ìò∏Ï∂úÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏûêÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìïú Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÎßûÎäîÏßÄ ÌôïÏù∏ -> Î≤àÍ±∞Î°úÏõÄ
    • If you know the pid of the process you want to wait for, you can use the waitpid( ) system call
    • The waitpid( ) call is a more powerful version of wait( ). Its additional parameters allow for fine-tuning
      • Provides some controls with options argument


    pid_t waitpid(pid_t pid, int *statloc, int options);

    • The pid parameter specifies exactly which process or processes to wait for.
    • pid == -1
      • Wait for any child process. This is the same behavior as wait( ).
    • pid > 0
      • Wait for any child process whose pid is exactly the value provided. For example, passing 500 waits for the child process with pid 500
      • pidÍ∞Ä 500Ïù∏ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Ï¢ÖÎ£åÎêòÏóàÏùÑ ÎïåÎßå Íπ®ÏõåÎã¨Îùº
    • pid == 0
      • Wait for any child process that belongs to the same process group as the calling process.
      • ÎÇòÌïòÍ≥† Í∞ôÏùÄ process groupÏù∏ Í≤ΩÏö∞Ïù¥Í∏∞Îßå ÌïòÎ©¥ Ïñ¥Îñ§ child processÎì†ÏßÄ Ï¢ÖÎ£åÎêòÎ©¥ Íπ®ÏõåÎã¨Îùº
    • pid < -1
      • Wait for any child process whose process group ID is equal to the absolute value of this value.
        • For example, passing -500 waits for any process in process group 500.


    waitpid option parameter

    • The status parameter works identically to the sole parameter to wait( )
    • option - > Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò ÎåÄÍ∏∞ Î∞©Î≤ï
    • WNOHANG
      • Do not block, but return immediately if no matching child process has already terminated (or stopped or continued)
        • if a child specified by pid is not terminated.
    • WUNTRACED
      • Do not block if a child specified by pid has stopped.
      • If set, WIFSTOPPED is set, even if the calling process is not tracing the child process.
      • Ïã§ÌñâÏùÑ Ï§ëÎã®Ìïú ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò ÏÉÅÌÉúÍ∞íÏùÑ Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
      • This flag allows for the implementation of more general job control, as in a shell.
    • WCONTINUED
      • If set, WIFCONTINUED is set even if the calling process is not tracing the child process.
      • ÏàòÌñâÏ§ëÏù∏ ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò ÏÉÅÌÉúÍ∞í Î¶¨ÌÑ¥
      • As with WUNTRACED, this flag is useful for implementing a shell
    • wait (&status);
      • is identical to waitpid (-1, &status, 0);
      • 0 -> no option


    wait() and waitpid()

    • Example
    #include "apue.h"
#include <sys/wait.h>
int main(void)
{
    pid_t pid;
    if ((pid = fork()) < 0) {
        err_sys("fork error");
    } else if (pid == 0) { /* first child */
        if ((pid = fork()) < 0)
            err_sys("fork error");
        else if (pid > 0)
            exit(0); /* parent from second fork == first child */
        /* We're the second child; our parent becomes init. */
        sleep(2);
        printf("second child, parent pid = %d\n", getppid());
        exit(0);
    }
    if (waitpid(pid, NULL, 0) != pid) /* wait for first child */
        err_sys("waitpid error");
    /*
 * We're the parent (the original process); we continue executing,
 * knowing that we're not the parent of the second child.
 */
    exit(0);
}

    $ ./a.out
$ second child, parent pid = 1


    PID 1742Ïù∏ ÏûêÏãùÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º wait (waitpid) ÏûêÏãùÏù¥ Ï¢ÖÎ£å ÏïàÎêú Í≤ΩÏö∞ Ï¶âÏãú Î¶¨ÌÑ¥

    int status;
pid_t pid;
pid = waitpid (1742, &status, WNOHANG); // Î∞îÎ°ú Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ (Ï¢ÖÎ£åÎ•º ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎçîÎùºÎèÑ)
if (pid == -1)
    perror ("waitpid");
else {
    printf ("pid=%d\n", pid);
    if (WIFEXITED (status)) // status check macro function
        printf ("Normal termination with exit status=%d\n", WEXITSTATUS (status));
    if (WIFSIGNALED (status))
        printf ("Killed by signal=%d%s\n",WTERMSIG (status), WCOREDUMP (status) ? " (dumped core)" : "");
}


    Zombies

    • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä wait()Ïù¥ÎÇò waitpid()Î•º Ìò∏Ï∂úÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïù¥Ï†ÑÏóê ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Ïù¥ÎØ∏ Ï¢ÖÎ£åÍ∞Ä ÎèºÎ≤ÑÎ¶∞ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º zombie processÎùºÍ≥† ÌïúÎã§.
      • ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏÉÅ Í∞ÄÎπÑÏßÄ Í∞úÎÖêÏúºÎ°ú Î¥êÎèÑ ÎêúÎã§.
    • a process that has terminated, but that has not yet been waited upon by its parent is called a ‚Äúzombie‚Äù
      • Ï¢ÄÎπÑ ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Îäî ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏóêÎßå Ï°¥Ïû¨
    • Zombie processes continue to consume system resources
    • wait() returns immediately with that child‚Äòs status
    • These resources remain so that parent processes that want to check up on the status of their children can obtain information relating to the life and termination of those processes.
    • Once the parent does so, the kernel cleans up the process for good and the zombie ceases(stop) to exist.


    waitpid.c

    #include <sys/types.h>
‚Ä¶
/* Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïòÍ≥† ÎÅùÎÇòÍ∏∞Î•º Í∏∞Îã§Î¶∞Îã§. */
int main()
{
    int pid1, pid2, child, status;

    printf("[%d] Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë \n", getpid( ));
    pid1 = fork();
    if (pid1 == 0) {
        printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§[1] ÏãúÏûë \n", getpid( ));
        sleep(1);
        printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§[1] Ï¢ÖÎ£å \n", getpid( ));
        exit(1);
    }

    pid2 = fork(); // ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÎèåÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÎèÑÏ§ëÏóêÎèÑ Ïù¥Î•º Ïã§Ìñâ
    if (pid2 == 0) {
        printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ [2] ÏãúÏûë \n", getpid( ));
        sleep(2);
        printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ [2] Ï¢ÖÎ£å \n", getpid( ));
        exit(2);
    }
    // ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ #1Ïùò Ï¢ÖÎ£åÎ•º Í∏∞Îã§Î¶∞Îã§.
    child = waitpid(pid1, &status, 0); //option 0: ÏûêÏãùÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Ï¢ÖÎ£åÌï†ÎïåÍπåÏßÄ wait
    printf("[%d] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ [1] %d Ï¢ÖÎ£å \n", getpid( ), child);
    printf("\tÏ¢ÖÎ£å ÏΩîÎìú %d\n", status>>8);
}

    $ waitpid
[16840] Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ÏãúÏûë
[16841] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§[1] ÏãúÏûë
[16842] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§[2] ÏãúÏûë
[16841] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§[1] Ï¢ÖÎ£å

Ï¢ÖÎ£åÏΩîÎìú 1
[16842] ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§[2] Ï¢ÖÎ£å

    sleepÏù¥ ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ ÎØ∏ÏπúÎã§.


    fork() ÌõÑÏóê ÌååÏùº Í≥µÏú†

    • ÏûêÏãùÏùÄ Î∂ÄÎ™®Ïùò fd ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏùÑ Î≥µÏÇ¨ÌïúÎã§.
      • Î∂ÄÎ™®ÏôÄ ÏûêÏãùÏù¥ Í∞ôÏùÄ ÌååÏùº ÎîîÏä§ÌÅ¨Î¶ΩÌÑ∞Î•º Í≥µÏú† (FD table, U area Î≥µÏÇ¨)
      • Í∞ôÏùÄ ÌååÏùº Ïò§ÌîÑÏÖãÏùÑ Í≥µÏú†
      • Î∂ÄÎ™®ÏôÄ ÏûêÏãùÏúºÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï∂úÎ†•Ïù¥ ÏÑúÎ°ú ÏÑûÏù¥Í≤å Îê®
    • ÏûêÏãùÏóêÍ≤å ÏÉÅÏÜçÎêòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÏÑ±Ïßà
      • fork()Ïùò Î∞òÌôòÍ∞í
        • Î¶¨ÌÑ¥ÏùÑ Îëê Î≤à Ìï®
      • ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ ID
      • Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïú ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Ïû†Í∏à, ÌååÏùº Ïû†Í∏à
      • ÏÑ§Ï†ïÎêú ÏïåÎûåÍ≥º ÏãúÍ∑∏ÎÑê


    fork()

    ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä ÏÉùÏÑ±ÎêòÎ©¥ ÎèôÏùºÌïú ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïùò file descriptorÎ•º Í∑∏ÎåÄÎ°ú Î≥µÏÇ¨ÌïòÍ≥† open file table Îí∑Îã®ÏùÄ Î™®Îëê Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÍ≤å ÎêúÎã§.(Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≥≥ÏùÑ Í∞ÄÎ¶¨ÌÇ¥)

    • per process table

    Í∞ôÏùÄ open file entryÎ•º Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÌååÏùº Ïò§ÌîÑÏÖãÏù¥ Í≥µÏú†ÎêòÏñ¥ ÎëòÏù¥ Í∞ôÏù¥ ÌååÏùºÏùÑ ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÎ©¥ Î∂ÄÎ™®ÏôÄ ÏûêÏãùÏúºÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï∂úÎ†•Ïù¥ ÏÑúÎ°ú ÏÑûÏùº Ïàò ÏûàÏùå


    Copy-on-write

    fork() Ïùò Ìö®Ïú®ÏÑ±ÏùÑ ÎÜíÏù¥Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú Î∞©Î≤ï

    • Copy-on-write is a lazy optimization strategy designed to mitigate the overhead of duplicating resources.
      • ÏûêÏãùÏùò duplicationÏùÑ Í∞ÄÎä•ÌïúÌïú ÏßÄÏó∞
    • The premise is simple:
      • if multiple consumers request read access to their own copies of a resource, duplicate copies of the resource need not be made. Instead, each consumer can be handed a pointer to the same resource. (Ï≤òÏùåÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ forkÌïòÎ©¥ Î∞îÎ°ú copyÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎèÑÎ°ù -> Í∞ôÏùÄ resourceÎ°ú Ìè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏Î°ú hand)
    • So long as no consumer attempts to modify its ‚Äúcopy‚Äù of the resource, the illusion of exclusive access to the resource remains, and the overhead of a copy is avoided.
      • ÏûêÍ∏∞ ÎßåÏùò resourceÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßÑÎã§Í≥† Ï∞©Í∞Å
    • If a consumer does attempt to modify its copy of the resource, at that point, the resource is transparently duplicated, and the copy is given to the modifying consumer
    • modifyÍ∞Ä ÏùºÏñ¥ÎÇòÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏö∞ÏóêÎäî Ìïú Í∞úÏùò copyÎßå Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù ÌïòÎã§Í∞Ä ÎßåÏïΩ Îëê ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ Ï§ëÏóêÏÑú Ìïú ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä modify ÌïòÍ≤å ÎêòÎ©¥ Í∑∏Ï†úÏÑúÏïº ÎπÑÎ°úÏÜå lazyÌïòÍ≤å Îí§Îä¶Í≤å copyÎ•º ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Ï§ÄÎã§.


    fork()

    Copy on write

    • After parent process write a page C.

    readÎßå ÌïòÎ©¥ Ìè¨Ïù∏ÌÑ∞Î•º Í≥µÏú†

    cÎßå modifyÎ•º ÌïòÍ≥†Ïûê ÌïòÎ©¥ Î≥ÑÎèÑÏùò copyÎ≥∏ÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ Í∞ÅÏûê Îã§Î•∏ Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í∞ÄÎ¶¨ÌÇ§Í≤å ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.


    Vfork()

    • Creates a new process only to exec a new program
      • ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ programÏùÑ Ïã§ÌñâÏãúÌÇ§Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú Î™©Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°úÎßå ÏÇ¨Ïö©
      • No copy of parent‚Äôs address space for child (not needed!)
      • Before exec, child runs in ‚Äúaddress space of parent‚Äù
        • Ï£ºÏÜå Í≥µÍ∞ÑÏùÑ Îã¨Î¶¨ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† parentÏùò Ï£ºÏÜå Í≥µÍ∞ÑÏóêÏÑú Ïã§Ìñâ
      • Efficient in paged virtual memory
    • Child runs first
      • Parent waits until child exec or exit (block)
        • Then the parent resume
      • The deadlock(blockÎêú ÏÉÅÌÉú) possibility if the child wait for something from the parent
        • Î∂ÄÎ™®Ïùò ÏûêÏõêÏùÑ ÌïÑÏöîÎ°úÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ -> deadlock Î∞úÏÉù Í∞ÄÎä• -> ÍµâÏû•Ìûà Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÎèôÍ∏∞Ìôî Í∏∞Ïà†Î°ú Ìï¥Í≤∞


    vfork()

    #include <unistd.h>

pid_t vfork(void);
 	//Returns: 0 in child, process ID of child in parent, -1 on error
    • same calling sequence and same return values as fork().
    • intended to create a new process when the purpose of the new process is to exec() a new program.
      • Does not copy the address space of parent into the child.
      • The child calls exec() or exit() right after the vfork().
      • The child runs in the address space of the parent. (exec() Ï†ÑÍπåÏßÄÎäî)
      • Provides an efficiency.
        • execÏù¥ Î∞îÎ°ú Ìò∏Ï∂úÎêòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Ïóê Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏûÑ
    • vfork() guarantees that the child runs first.


    • Example
    #include "apue.h‚Äú
int glob = 6; /* external variable in initialized data */
int main(void)
{
    int var; /* automatic variable on the stack */
    pid_t pid;
    var = 88;
    
    printf("before vfork\n"); /* we don't flush stdio */
    if ((pid = vfork()) < 0) {
        err_sys("vfork error");
    } else if (pid == 0) { /* child */
        glob++; /* modify parent's variables */
        var++;
        exit(0); /* child terminates */
    }
    /*
 * Parent continues here.
 */
    printf("pid = %d, glob = %d, var = %d\n", getpid(), glob, var);
    exit(0);
}
    • Ïã§Ìñâ (13 ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ fork Í≤ΩÏö∞ÏôÄÏùò Ï∞®Ïù¥Ï†ê)
    $ ./a.out
before vfork
pid = 29039, glob = 7, var = 89
$

    vforkÎäî ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Î•º Ï¶âÏãú Î≥µÏ†úÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† exec()ÏùÑÌïòÍ∏∞ Ï†ÑÍπåÏßÄÎäî ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïùò Ï£ºÏÜå Í≥µÍ∞ÑÏóêÏÑú Ïã§ÌñâÎêúÎã§. Îî∞ÎùºÏÑú ÏûêÏãù ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Î≥ÄÏàò(var, glob)ÏùÑ Ï¶ùÍ∞Ä ÏãúÏº∞ÎäîÎç∞ ÏûêÏãùÍ≥º Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä glob, var Î≥ÄÏàòÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ Î≥ÑÎèÑÎ°ú copyÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Î∂ÄÎ™® ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Í∞Ä Í∞ñÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Î∂ÄÎ™®Í∞Ä Ï¶ùÍ∞ÄÏãúÌÇ§ÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎçîÎùºÎèÑ ÏûêÏãùÏù¥ Ï¶ùÍ∞ÄÏãúÌÇ® Í≤É ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Î∂ÄÎ™®Í∞Ä Ï∂úÎ†•ÌïòÎäî ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïóê Ïù¥Í≤ÉÏù¥ Î∞òÏòÅÎêòÏñ¥ ÎÇòÌÉÄÎÇòÍ≤å Îêú Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.

    Í≥†Î°ú Ïù¥ Ï†êÏù¥ fork() ÏôÄÏùò Ï∞®Ïù¥Ï†êÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§.
